Award.AwardTitle: IDBR: Agile Electronic Focus and Aberration Control for Live Animal Microscopy
Award.AbstractNarration:
A grant has been awarded to Dr. David Dickensheets at Montana State University to develop a light microscope with agile electronic focus control. This project addresses a major technological barrier for in vivo microscopy: controlling the focus and managing aberrations when imaging through thick, unprepared specimens. We will investigate a method that adjusts the location of the focus in the sample under electronic control while maintaining the objective lens in a fixed position. This instrument will be compatible with CCD-based or scanned beam (confocal and two photon) types of microscopes, and will give the user fast, full-range focus control when imaging thick specimens at high numerical aperture, without requiring z-translation of the specimen stage.

Of the several possible technologies for beam focus control, MEMS deformable membrane mirrors are attractive for their precision, speed and potential low cost. However, previous implementations have suffered from limited range of motion, such that full range focus control at high NA was not possible. This project will develop new MEMS membrane mirrors capable of an order of magnitude more displacement than current devices and able to correct spherical aberration to maintain high Strehl ratio throughout the image volume. The improvement is achieved through the use of new membrane materials, accurate mechanical modeling and a new closed loop control technique for stable electrostatic actuation. This project will develop the new mirrors and control techniques, and demonstrate their use in a new instrument for two different confocal microscopy applications: microscopy of the developing chick embryo, and microscopy of human skin in vivo.

The scope of potential use for this technology is quite broad. The new instrument could support many sophisticated image acquisition schemes including oblique sectioning, enhanced depth of focus at high NA, and image feature tracking and stabilization. The technology is also critical for future miniaturized microscopes designed for laparoscope, endoscope or catheter platforms that presently have extremely limited ability to adjust focus in situ. Finally, advances made in this project will be relevant for a broad class of electrostatic MEMS actuators and the deformable mirrors will be of interest for applications in astronomy, photography, optical data storage and others. In addition to its scientific impact the project embraces integration of research and education, training two engineering Ph.D. students in cross disciplinary research and engaging 6 undergraduate students in engineering design teams. This project will also participate in an established summer internship program for students and faculty from Montana?s tribal colleges.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research is developing new technology for fast, electronic focus control for live animal microscopy. The way we focus a microscope hasn’t changed much in 100 years – and involves moving either the sample or else a heavy lens – it cannot be done rapidly nor precisely enough to track a moving target like the beating heart of a developing chick embryo. Our objective is to be able to see with cellular resolution and in real time the development of live animals at the very earliest stages when critical differentiation of tissues is occurring, experiments that are not possible without improved instrumentation.

 Conventional scanning laser microscopes like the confocal microscope employ galvanometer mirrors to scan a laser beam quickly in the x-y plane, but rely on motorized focus adjustment to “scan” in the z direction. This limits “real time” observations to a single horizontal plane. But confocal microscopes allow imaging in 3D living tissue, and often the surface of interest to the scientist is not a horizontal plane – it may be a tilted or vertical plane, or a more complicated shape altogether. Existing instruments can’t image those surfaces directly.

To address this challenge we are using micro-electro-mechanical systems (MEMS) techniques to build small, millimeter-dimension mirrors whose surface curvature may be controlled electronically. The mirror serves as a variable-focus lens, allowing us to change instrument focus in much less than a millisecond. Now, the location of the beam focus (in z) can be synchronized to scanning in x and y, to allow oblique or vertical sections or to follow complex surfaces in the tissue. Using a computer to control where the instrument focuses, we will be able one day to do real-time tracking and image stabilization to accomplish cellular microscopy of moving, living subjects.

During this project we extended the capability of our MEMS focus control mirrors both in range of focus (stroke) and speed of operation. Our new mirrors achieved a displacement stroke greater than 16 microns, 4 times greater than our starting point. This mirror can change the focus of a 1.0 NA microscope over a depth of 85 microns. With a bandwidth of up to 20 KHz, these same mirrors are more than 10 times faster than the state-of-the-art at the beginning of the project, and fast enough to keep pace with the galvanometer x-y scanners to allow agile 3D surface scanning. We demonstrated this by inserting our MEMS focus control device into an Olympus FluoView confocal fluorescence microscope. With the new device installed, we were able to image not only fixed x-y planes, but also oblique planes and vertical planes, at the full acquisition speed of the instrument. This project therefore succeeded in developing a new active focus control device that will offer the microscopist interactive control to choose the surfaces within a 3D sample that will be imaged, stimulated, or recorded from, speeding data acquisition and extending observation times. We are now working to transfer our technology to an industrial partner for commercialization.

The application of MEMS focus control mirrors to biological confocal microscopy is just getting started as this project concludes. The future potential impact on society is significant. As we improve the imaging tools we use to study developing organisms, we improve the types of experiments that we can conduct to better understand mechanisms of biological development, the influence of environment, and causes and cures for disease.
